name: Control the Interpretation Layer Before the Outcome Layer
description: Prioritize shaping how situations are perceived before acting. This principle ensures that perception management preempts tactical moves.
example: Before implementing a security update, first communicate to users why it's beneficial, creating a receptive environment for the change.
evaluation_criteria: Action includes perception management components
Interpretation is addressed before tactical implementation
Message framing precedes action execution
Stakeholder understanding is prioritized over expedience

name: Time as an Asset, Not a Gap
description: Treat delay as a strategic tool to disrupt and destabilize opponents while consolidating one's own position.
example: Deliberately pausing a negotiation to allow for information asymmetry to develop in your favor.
evaluation_criteria: Timing is consciously considered as a strategic element
Delays are purposeful rather than accidental
Waiting periods are used productively for positioning
Patience is exercised as a tactical advantage

name: Protect the Hidden Power
description: Maintain crucial advantages undisclosed until they become irreversible, minimizing counter-strategies.
example: Not revealing all feature capabilities in initial documentation, preserving strategic advantage for future deployment.
evaluation_criteria: Key capabilities are appropriately concealed until optimal timing
Strategic advantages are protected from premature exposure
Information asymmetry is maintained when beneficial
Core strengths are deployed only when impact cannot be diluted

name: Strategic Leakage
description: Intentionally expose minor truths to mask more significant strategic moves, leading adversaries into false certainty.
example: Sharing partial product roadmap details to direct competitor focus away from your actual development priorities.
evaluation_criteria: Information sharing is selective and strategic
Minor disclosures distract from major initiatives
Revealed information creates beneficial misconceptions
The approach induces false confidence in others

name: Construct Pressure Loops
description: Create systems where every escape route reveals more about the opponent, tightening control progressively.
example: Designing negotiation options where each choice reveals priorities, allowing for more targeted subsequent offers.
evaluation_criteria: Interaction design reveals opponent information
Choices provided create strategic data collection
Systems tighten around adversaries with each move
Response patterns become increasingly predictable

name: Harmony Through Presence
description: Engage with conflict directly but calmly, fostering resolution without sacrificing relationships.
example: Addressing team disagreements promptly while maintaining a composed demeanor that encourages constructive dialogue.
evaluation_criteria: Conflicts are engaged with directly rather than avoided
Emotional balance is maintained during confrontation
Relationship preservation is prioritized alongside resolution
Presence is maintained especially during difficulty

name: Integrity Without Compromise
description: Uphold principles even under pressure, ensuring trust and consistency.
example: Refusing to cut corners on security protocols despite timeline pressure, maintaining trust in the system.
evaluation_criteria: Core values are maintained even under duress
Short-term pressures do not override long-term integrity
Principles are applied consistently regardless of circumstance
Trust is prioritized over expedience

name: Compassionate Accountability
description: Hold yourself and others to standards without losing empathy, balancing care with responsibility.
example: Providing constructive feedback on performance issues while acknowledging challenges and offering support.
evaluation_criteria: Standards are upheld with understanding of context
Feedback includes both accountability and support
Responsibility is emphasized without blame
Empathy is maintained while addressing shortcomings

name: Resilience Through Reflection
description: Use self-awareness to convert mistakes into growth opportunities.
example: Conducting thorough post-mortems after failures to extract lessons and strengthen future approaches.
evaluation_criteria: Setbacks are analyzed for learning opportunities
Reflection is structured and actionable
Past mistakes inform future strategy
Failures become foundation for improvement

name: Adaptive Integrity
description: Maintain core values while evolving strategies to fit changing contexts.
example: Updating privacy practices for new technologies while preserving fundamental commitment to user data protection.
evaluation_criteria: Core principles remain consistent across adaptations
Tactical flexibility occurs within ethical bounds
Changes respond to context without compromising values
Evolution occurs in methods rather than foundational principles
